event: Pre-Columbian cultures, including the Nahua, Chorotega, and Nicarao peoples, inhabit the region.
Christopher Columbus explores the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua during his fourth voyage.
Spanish conquistador Francisco Hernández de Córdoba founds Granada and León.
Nicaragua becomes part of the Spanish Captaincy General of Guatemala.
Nicaragua declares independence from Spain.
Nicaragua joins the United Provinces of Central America.
Nicaragua becomes a fully independent republic.
American adventurer William Walker declares himself president of Nicaragua; later ousted by Central American forces.
José Santos Zelaya establishes a liberal dictatorship and modernizes the country.
U.S. supports a rebellion that overthrows Zelaya; period of U.S. influence begins.
Civil war begins; Augusto César Sandino leads a guerrilla movement against U.S. Marines.
Sandino assassinated; Anastasio Somoza García rises to power.
Somoza becomes president, establishing the Somoza family dictatorship.
Devastating earthquake strikes Managua; government corruption hampers recovery.
Sandinista revolution overthrows Somoza regime; FSLN takes power.
U.S. begins funding Contra rebels against Sandinista government.
Violeta Chamorro defeats Sandinistas in election, becoming first female president in Latin America.
Daniel Ortega returns to power as president.
Mass protests erupt against Ortega’s government; violent crackdown follows.
Ortega wins fourth consecutive term amid international criticism and opposition arrests.
